titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the David Andrew Hunter Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Logan Hill

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 10:53

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correspondence, topical files and photographs. Correspondence and topical files document David Hunter's attempts to prove that his post-war illnesses were service-related and to gain compensation. The photographs are of the Far East during World War II.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of David A. Hunter, Jr., 1988.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: David Andrew Hunter Papers (MS 1486). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The papers are arranged in three series: Series I. Correspondence, 1942-1958. Series II. Topical Files, 1942-1958. Series III. Photographs, 1958, undated

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: David Andrew Hunter was born on March 24, 1904 in New Orleans, Louisiana. He graduated from Warren Easton High School in 1921. He studied for one year at Tulane University and eventually worked at Kessler Insurance Company in New Orleans. He married Belle Watson in 1930. Their son, David Andrew Hunter, Jr. was born in 1931. David Hunter, Sr. enlisted in the Army on June 23, 1942 in New Orleans. As an Intelligence Officer in the Office of Strategic Services, Hunter served in Burma, India, China and Thailand. Hunter received an honorable discharge on April 6, 1946, and returned to New Orleans. Thereafter, he became ill with dysentery and malaria. He attempted to prove his illness was service-related in order to receive compensation, but was unsuccessful. David Andrew Hunter died on May 19, 1958.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of correspondence, topical files and photographs. Correspondence and topical files document David Hunter's attempts to prove that his post-war illnesses were service-related and to gain compensation. The photographs are of the Far East during World War II.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

controlaccess.subject: Military pensions
Veterans -- Medical care
Veterans -- United States
World War, 1939-1945 -- Campaigns -- Burma
World War, 1939-1945
controlaccess.corpname: United States. Office of Strategic Services

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence is arranged in two sections: "Family" and "Other." Within each section, letters are arranged chronologically. The "Family" section contains letters written by Hunter to his wife and son during his service in World War II. The letters reveal very little about the course of the war or Hunter's role in it. Hunter comments mainly on family matters and foreign culture and landscapes. The "Other" section primarily includes letters written by non-family members on behalf of Hunter in his attempt to gain compensation for his illnesses. Typically, the writers address the capacity in which they were familiar with Hunter and praise his character. Copies of Hunter's solicitations for such assistance are frequently attached.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is arranged alphabetically. Most materials relate to Hunter's medical problems and attempts to obtain compensation from the Red Cross, Social Security Administration and Veteran's Administration. The "Medical record" file is the most informative pertaining to his illnesses. "Military record" provides extensive biographical information. "Memos and directives" includes information on Hunter's military transfers and duties. "Prisoners of War, Siam" contains a draft by Hunter of a work that describes the American prisoners of war he evacuated from Siam in August, 1945.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs are arranged in two sections: "Identified" and "Unidentified." Within these sections they are arranged alphabetically by topic. The majority are undated. They are comprised of black and white photographs, 2" x 3.5", 3" x 5", and 8" x 10". On the whole, the photographs are in good condition, but some have faded. A few of the 8" by 10" photographs are of superior quality. This is the most interesting series in the collection. It contains hundreds of photographs of the landscape, culture, indigenous peoples and American soldiers in the Far East during World War II.
